posts.subject: pomfpomf.moe 0gallery hub
posts.body:
This is the 1PomfMoe-0gallery tagging help thread.

[Here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1PomfMoeTPxQ5gLJBeD1sBvaizxbHxf8Zv/) is the link to the 0gallery-hub. They are 475 doujins(all in english) on there, totaling around 6.3 GB(thumbnails and images combined), so if you could press the `Download and help distribute all files`-button in the 0-menu in the top right would help out a lot.

>What?
I made a 0gallery hub for the pomfpomf.moe siderip in >>346d0031-91ab-437f-894b-5ff91c73d67d.
However: At the moment all galleries on there are not tagged(aside from the lolicon tag) and have no description. Doing that all by myself will take forever, since I don't have that much time I can dedicate to it. So if you want to help me tag the galleries on there, you can just post the name of the doujinshi, that you tagged along with your description and your name, if you want to be credited for your tagging help. You can search for untagged galleries, by searching the `JustGotParsed:NeedsToBeTagged`-tag.
Guidelines for tags:
- Try to stick to the e-hentai/exhentai/sadpanda tag naming conventions
- Language tags are not necessary, since the language is defined outside of the tags.

This thread can also be used for general discussion/questions relating to this 0gallery hub.

>Sorry for the delayed reply, anon.
No problem**, real life can be a bitch**.
>What I meant is to use a key file + password.
That is better, however (against state actors or a dedicated hacker) using a keyfile with a weak password will be no obstacle, so you would have to use a strong password in combination with the keyfile, at which point you could just use the strong password. Keyfiles do not increase (encryption-)key entropy as much as one would think, and have no effect at all(on entropy), if you have a 32(ASCII) character password(assuming 256-bit AES). Although, using a keyfile is in general an security improvement over not using one. One just needs to keep in mind, that it is probably a lot less improvement than one would think.

>>fd41bc46-7343-41e3-a7c0-060a7bc77a43
>Let's say one has N files that could be used as a key file.
My bad, I thought you meant these key-usb sticks, that you can use to encrypt/decrypt stuff with. 
>This seems to increase the attack cost by a factor of N which can be a significant improvement considering the size of N and the original attack cost.
You are correct, but its more like an factor of ln(N), since while you keep adding more and more files, your encryption key can only have 256-bits of entropy at max(at least for most blockcyphers). So the entropy increase going from N=0 to N=1 will be way higher, than the increase from N=20 to N=21.(I'm talking about entropy here, because the number of permutations that one has to bruteforce((N+1)! and not just N+1, mind you) increases way faster, than bruteforcing the entropy of the key(**approximately** 2^n ), therefore bruteforcing the entropy becomes favorable really quickly)

>I guess it might have been the translator's
The first release was in English, the Russian translation came later, so the style probably wasn't appealing to you. **Or have you red the Russian version first?**.
>What do you mean?
You would think that YT, being a company that lives off selling people/personal data, would find and purge most pedo stuff off their platform and report the info(IPs, e-mails, telephone numbers, social trees ...) they have to the three letter friends out there. But I have never heard of anyone getting tipped of by YT, which is amazing to me. Then again, maybe it's just not against the law enough over there, to do anything, so they just maintain a naughty list somewhere in case the three letter friends do decide to come over.
>It's a good way of practicing new languages too if that's your thing.
I assume Russian is the first thing I would learn or is that just a stereotype?
>I'm not sure if something like that would actually work well in the current state of ZeroNet though.
Maybe api things aside, I don't see why not, the issue with videos in zeronet right now is as far as I can tell, that once you have watched an video you're basically done with it and move on. You have no real intention or reason to seed it, this leaves tons of videos unseeded if they are older than let's say a week or so. That isn't an issue for live streams, the only time you seed/contribute to it is still while you actively watch it and then it's done and everyone moves on. Thinking about it live streams are probably also better than videos from a legal standpoint, because you have(to some extend) plausible deniability, since you can't know what comes next in the stream and you discard it the moments after you have seen it. Zeronet certainly has the best chances, can't see Tor, I2P, much less Freenet being an viable option, anyway. Maybe ipfs or gnunet, but I don't know enough about these to say anything.

posts.subject: Qubes and ZeroNet
posts.body:
I made some instructions on how to install Zeronet on Qubes. You can find them [here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1PexoLogqCsGAwYEUNqKnmzccg1r5tzCZ3/?Post:5:How+to+install+Zeronet+on+QubesOS), but if you don't want to download the zite to read it, I'll post them here as well.
==Note:==
The update to Tor Browser 8.0 breaks these instructions. I'm currently looking into that, but for the time being use the Tor Browser 7.5.6 and not 8.0 in the steps below, as an workaround. Updating from 7.5.6 to 8.0 in the appVMs works, it only breaks if you have 8.0 in your templateVM.

posts.subject: Requirements and assumptions
posts.body:
>>0d40b673-efd1-40bd-92b2-90690c51615b
-I'll be using the fedora 28 templateVM for the Zeronet templateVM. The basic procedure should the same for older fedora versions, but can differ slightly, so be aware of that, should you want to use a different fedora template.

-I'll also be assuming Qubes 4, but older Qubes versions shouldn't make much of a difference, at least as far as I'm aware of.

-Anything in {curly braces} needs to be replaced by something. Example: `tor-browser-linux64-{someversion}_en-US.tar.xz` could be `tor-browser-linux64-7.5.5_en-US.tar.xz` or `tor-browser-linux64-7.5.6_en-US.tar.xz`.

posts.subject: The Setup
posts.body:
>>beb0d2bf-26c0-4ed0-a8e2-45d1963a06af
'''''1.''''' Open the Qubes manager and clone the fedora 28 templateVM. The name can be anything you want, I named it ZeronetTemplateVM.

'''''2.''''' In the Qube Manager open the `Qube Settings` section for the VM you just cloned and set under networking any netVM that has internet access. I'd choose `sys-whonix`, since that forces all traffic in our installation process through Tor, as well.

'''''3.''''' In the same window move to `Applications` and select `Terminal` and `Firefox`. You can also select other applications, but we only need Firefox and the terminal. You may need to press `Refresh Applications` before they appear. After you're done you can hit `Apply` and close the window.

'''''4.''''' Start the VM and open Firefox and it's terminal.

'''''5.''''' In Firefox download: The Zero Bundle from `zeronet.io`, the Tor Browser and it's signature from `torproject.org`.

'''''6.''''' Now get the public key fingerprints from `torproject.org` and import them into gpg with:
[code]gpg --recv-keys {key1} {key2} {...}[/code]
__Note__: At the time of this writing the command to get all keys is: `gpg --recv-keys 0x4E2C6E8793298290 0xEB774491D9FF06E2 0xD1483FA6C3C07136`, but times change and I STRONGLY discourage anyone from copying and pasting random signing keys from anywhere. I could claim just about anything I want and you wouldn't know, whether that really were the Tor Browser signing keys or I lied to you.

'''''7.''''' Verify the signature of the Tor Browser, to do this:
[code]cd /home/user/Downloads/[/code]
[code]gpg --verify tor-browser-linux64-{someversion}_en-US.tar.xz.asc tor-browser-linux64-{someversion}_en-US.tar.xz[/code]
Should the signature fail, redownload the Tor Browser and the signature and try again. Should it fail again, wait a day and then redownload the Tor Browser and the signature and try again. If it continues to fail, report what failed to `torproject.org`.

posts.subject: Installing Tor
posts.body:
>>739c1f74-3c85-4718-a28e-86a836b132d2
'''''1.''''' Give yourself root privileges in the terminal
[code]sudo -i[/code]

'''''2.''''' Install Tor with:
[code]sudo dnf install tor[/code]
Confirm that you want to install Tor and wait for the installation to finish.

'''''3.''''' Now we need to configure Tor. We do this, by editing the torrc file:
[code]sudo gedit /etc/tor/torrc[/code]
Here you'll need to remove the `#` character in the lines that say `CookieAuthentication 1` and `ControlPort 9051`.
__Note__: The auth-cookie entry might be inside there multiple times, if you have no experience with editing the torrc file, just remove the `#` character from all appearing instances.
__Note2__: If one of them is not present in the entire file type them in yourself and make sure, that there isn't a `#` character somewhere before it in the same line.
Now save and close gedit.

'''''4.''''' We need to add permission for the default user `user` to read the Tor auth-cookie with(if your default user is not `user` change the word `user` in the command below to your default user name):
[code]sudo usermod -a -G toranon user[/code]

posts.subject: Starting Tor
posts.body:
>>6f52d2dc-8482-474d-92f1-76b36662fd86
For the next step we need Tor running, so open a new terminal window and run:
[code]sudo runuser -u toranon tor[/code]
This will start the Tor instance.

posts.subject: Installing Zeronet
posts.body:
>>91476162-4c1e-432e-a92e-225d863597f1
Now we can get to the installation of the Zero Bundle.

'''''1.''''' Go back to your download directory(if you left it) and unpack the Zero Bundle with:
[code]cd /home/user/Downloads/[/code]
[code]tar xvf ZeroBundle-linux64.tar.gz[/code]

'''''2.''''' Copy the unpacked folder into /usr/share:
[code]sudo cp -r ZeroBundle/ /usr/share/ZeroBundle[/code]

'''''3.''''' Now we need to configure Zeronet, to do that we have to run Zeronet for the first time, so that it can download the newest version(make sure you are still in root terminal):
[code]cd /usr/share/ZeroBundle/[/code]
[code]./ZeroNet.sh --version[/code]
This will download the most recent Zeronet version and print out the version after its done.
__Note__: In the current version of Zeronet(Version: 0.6.3 r3576) you'll see an error here, you can run the command again and it should produce the expected output.

'''''4.''''' Now, that the newest version has been downloaded, we can start Zeronet for real with:
[code]./ZeroNet.sh --tor always[/code]
If all downloads are finished, you can shut down Zeronet (either normally or by pressing `ctrl+c` in the terminal)
__Note__: If Firefox doesn't open automatically, open it yourself, type `127.0.0.1:43110` in the url field and press enter.

'''''5.''''' From here on out we don't need Tor running anymore, so in the terminal where Tor was running you can terminate the process(with `ctrl+c`) and close the window.

'''''6.''''' Right now the `ZeroBundle` folder is owned by root, so we need to change it's ownership.
[code]sudo chown -R user:user /usr/share/ZeroBundle/[/code]

'''''7.''''' Now we remove the generated data-directory, since we wont be using it:
[code]cd ZeroNet/[/code]
[code]sudo rm -r data/[/code]

'''''8.''''' After that, it is time to modify the config file. To do this run:
[code]sudo gedit zeronet.conf[/code]
Remove anything, that is written in there and replace it with:
[code]
[global]
open_browser = False
data_dir = /home/user/ZeronetData
tor = always
trackers_proxy = tor
force_encryption
disable_udp
[/code]
__Explanation__:
-`open_browser = False`: Makes it so, that the main browser(Firefox) won't be opened each time Zeronet is started.
-`data_dir = /home/user/ZeronetData`: This is the directory where all Zeronet data will be stored. You may change this to wherever you like.
-`tor = always`: This forces Zeronet to make all connections through .onion addresses(the Tor network). If you want to enable connections to regular IP addresses replace `always` with `enable`, however if you do this you are __no longer anonymous__, meaning others can see your real IP-address in the network.
-`trackers_proxy = tor`: This forces Zeronet to make all tracker connections through the Tor network.
-`force_encryption`: This forces Zeronet only to connect to peers, that offer to encrypt the traffic.
-`disable_udp`: Since Tor is set to `always` and all tracker connections are forced through Tor, allowing udp is pointless, since Tor only allows tcp connections.
You can also add other options in there, if you want. Once you're done you can save and close gedit.

posts.subject: Make Zeronet and Tor automatically start
posts.body:
>>c8b03cb0-692d-4f86-93e1-d27ff11d5d78
Now we need to make Zeronet and Tor start automatically, if the VM is started.
__Note__: We'll use ''init.d'' instead of ''/rw/config/rc.local'', because ''/rw/config/rc.local'' is not inherited by any appVM that uses the Zeronet-templateVM, therefore one would need to setup ''rc.local'' for each new Zeronet appVM, which is annoying and defeats the purpose of having an templateVM)
To achieve that we:

'''''1.''''' Go to init.d:
[code]cd /etc/init.d/[/code]

'''''2.''''' Create our auto start script:
[code]sudo gedit start-zeronet[/code]
In the appearing window paste:
[code]
#!/bin/bash
# chkconfig: 345 99 10
# description: A script to start Zeronet on boot time.

case "$1" in
 'start')
   ##Start Tor and save it's pid
   runuser -u toranon tor &
   tor_PID=$!
   echo $tor_PID > /home/user/.tor.pid
   ##Start Zeronet and save it's pid
   runuser -u user /usr/share/ZeroBundle/ZeroNet.sh &
   zeronet_PID=$!
   echo $zeronet_PID > /home/user/.zeronet.pid
   ;;
 'stop')
   ##Getting the pid for Zeronet, stoping it and removing it's pid file
   if [ -f /home/user/.zeronet.pid ] ; then 
     zeronet_PID=$(</home/user/.zeronet.pid);
     kill $zeronet_PID
     rm /home/user/.zeronet.pid
   fi
   ##Getting the pid for Tor, stoping it and removing it's pid file
   if [ -f /home/user/.tor.pid ] ; then 
     tor_PID=$(</home/user/.tor.pid);
     kill $tor_PID
     rm /home/user/.tor.pid
   fi
   ;;
esac
[/code]
__Explanation__:
The script starts Tor and Zeronet in background processes and stores their process id(=PID) into hidden files in the `/home/user` directory, as `tor.pid` and `zeronet.pid` respectively.
You can make modifications to this script as you see fit, once you're done you can save and exit gedit.

'''''3.''''' Need to make the script executable with:
[code]sudo chmod +x start-zeronet[/code]

'''''4.''''' Check whether or not the script is valid:
[code]sudo chkconfig --list start-zeronet[/code]
If the script didn't show up: Redo step 2. It is likely that you had a typo somewhere.

'''''5.''''' Register the script with:
[code]sudo chkconfig --add start-zeronet[/code]

posts.subject: Installing the Tor Browser
posts.body:
>>dbd6e825-629f-45af-908e-93d49e657039
Now we just need to install the Tor Browser and we are done.
To do this:

'''''1.''''' Go back to the downloads directory and unpack the Tor Browser bundle:
[code]cd /home/user/Downloads[/code]
[code]tar -xvf tor-browser-linux64-{someversion}_en-US.tar.xz[/code]

'''''2.''''' Move the Tor Browser to `/usr/local.orig/share` and change the owner of the moved folder to the default user:
[code]sudo mv tor-browser_en-US/ /usr/local.orig/share/tor-browser_en-US/[/code]
[code]sudo chown -R user:user /usr/local.orig/share/tor-browser_en-US/[/code]

'''''3.''''' Now go there and run the Tor Browser for the fist time(this will set all paths inside the .desktop file to the current location):
[code]cd /usr/local.orig/share/tor-browser_en-US/[/code]
[code]sudo runuser -u user ./start-tor-browser.desktop[/code]
You might be asked how you want to connect to Tor, if you government or ISP restricts your internet, follow the instructions on screen, otherwise press `connect`.

'''''4.''''' You can now configure our Tor Browser however you want, but what you absolutely have to do in order for Zeronet to work is:

-Click the green onion button in the top left(or sometimes top right), press `Security Settings...` and move the slider all the way up(to safest).
-Select the NoScript icon, click `Options...`, than on `Whitelist`, put `http://127.0.0.1:43110` in the `Address of web site:` text field and press the `Allow` button. You can then hit `OK` to save and close the window.
-Go into Preferences, under `Advanced`, click on `Network` and press the `Settings...` button next to `Configure how Tor Browser connects to the Internet`. In the `No Proxy for:` field add `127.0.0.1/43110`, than hit `OK`, to close the window.
What I think is nice to have enabled(=you don't need to do this):
-Go into Preferences and under `General` change the homepage to `127.0.0.1:43110`(this sets the homepage to the IP and port of the Zeronet ui-server)
-Go into Preferences, under `Advanced`, click on `General` and check `Use autoscrolling`. This enables autoscrolling(=the scroll thingy that appears, if you middle-mouse-click on most browsers).
You can now close the Tor Browser and return to the terminal.

posts.subject: Fixing the Tor Browser .desktop file
posts.body:
>>018d819c-ac70-4470-a4cd-9d04f550c644
Now, that we have our setup done, we just need to prepare the .desktop file for the Tor Browser, so that we can select it in the `add/remove app shortcuts for this qube` section of the Qubes manager.
To do that, we need to move the .desktop file for the Tor Browser to an location that can be found by Qubes, in our case `/usr/share/applications`:

'''''1.''''' We make a copy of start-tor-browser.desktop and place it into `/usr/share/applications` with:
[code]sudo cp start-tor-browser.desktop /usr/share/applications/start-tor-browser.desktop[/code]

'''''2.''''' We then need to go there and adjust the permissions for the desktop file.
[code]cd /usr/share/applications/[/code]
[code]sudo chmod 644 start-tor-browser.desktop[/code]

'''''3.''''' The way inheritance works in Qubes with templateVMs is, that anything inside the `/usr/local.orig/` directory in the templateVM will end up inside `/usr/local/` in the appVM. So we need to adjust the paths inside the .desktop file, to match that new destination:
[code]sudo gedit start-tor-browser.desktop[/code]
In there change, all instances of `local.orig` to `local`, except for the line starting with `Icon=`. That should be 2 instances.
Once you are done, you can save and close gedit.

And with that you are done with the templateVM, you can now close all open windows and shut the VM down.

posts.subject: Creating an Zeronet appVM
posts.body:
>>85d7920d-eedc-4bc5-85ca-7c3e1d81c4b2
Now you'll just need to create an appVM, in which you'll actually use Zeronet.
To do that:

'''''1.''''' In Qubes select `Create a new qube`.

'''''2.''''' Choose what you want to name it.

'''''3.''''' Select `appVM` as the type.

'''''4.''''' Take the Zeronet templateVM(the one we just made) as template and use whichever netVM you want.
__Note__: Since we instructed Zeronet to make all connections through to selecting `sys-whonix` would mean we go through Tor twice. The safest and fasted choice here would be to choose an VPN netVM, to catch any leaks or potential mistakes you make, but choosing `sys-firewall` as netVM is also alright, if you don't have to worry about leaks or mistakes on your end, that may reveal your real IP.

'''''5.''''' Click finish to continue.

'''''6.''''' After the qube is created right click the VM and click `add/remove app shortcuts`.

'''''7.''''' Select the `Tor Browser` and add any application you also want to have. Keep in mind that you may have to refresh the applications before the Tor Browser shows up there.
__Note__: If you're only going to use this qube for Zeronet browsing, you don't need to select Firefox, since you're always going to use the Tor Browser to do that, anyway.

posts.subject: Updating Zeronet
posts.body:
>>b32a3424-bcc8-47c0-ba08-830b5059affd
To update Zeronet, you need to start the templateVM and the Tor Browser. However we can't use the app shortcut for the templateVM in Qubes itself for that, because we changed the paths to work for the appVMs, so you have to use another way to open the Tor Browser. To do this open the terminal and run:
[code]cd /usr/local.orig/share/tor-browser_en-US/`[/code]
Followed by:
[code]./start-tor-browser.desktop[/code]
This will start the Tor Browser.
If you do this the first time, you'll see that Zeronet is downloading `ZeroHello` again, that makes sense, because we deleted the data/ directory and specified a new data directory(inside the home folder) in the setup above.
Wait until Zeronet is finished downloading and then update Zeronet as you would always do:

-Clicking the three dots.

-Clicking `Version{version}({rev}):{status}`.

-Confirm the dialogue, that pops up by pressing `Update ZeroNet{version}`.

-Wait until the `Connection with UiServer Websocket recovered.` message appears.

After the update is done, you can shut down Zeronet and after that the templateVM as well.
__Note__: You also can visit and download `http://127.0.0.1:43110/1UPDatEDxnvHDo7TXvq6AEBARfNkyfxsp/`, before you update. This will cause all updates to be downloaded, using Zeronet itself.
From that point on all appVMs, that have that templateVM, will have the new Zeronet version installed.

Now you need to click the green onion icon ton the top left(sometimes top right) and select `Check for Tor Browser Update...`. The Tor Browser will now automatically update itself. After it is done, you can close the Tor Browser and shutdown the templateVM.

posts.subject: Things to keep in mind
posts.body:
>>999d3d52-d670-4989-8398-e61f7583d8e4
-The Tor Browser is only inherited once, meaning that after you have created an appVM from the templateVM, the Tor Browser in that appVM __will not__ be influenced by the templateVM. In other words: Changes, that you make in the templateVM Tor Browser, will __not__ be automatically on all appVMs, that have been created from the templateVM! The changes __only__ appear in appVMs that are created __after__ the changes to the templateVM Tor Browser were made!

>>1fc2497f-4d92-46d0-bfd6-2dadb8fe7170
I gave it some thought an I think this would work well enough:
-Take ''sha256(Auth_address+Post_time+post_uuidv4+Board_Owner_Address)'' **or any other 256 bit hash** 
-Limit the hash to range ''0x1'' to ''0xFFFF FFFF FFFF FFFF FFFF FFFF FFFF FFFE BAAE DCE6 AF48 A03B BFD2 5E8C D036 4140'' (the hash ''mod the_big_number'' and then ''+1'' should be enough)
This will now represent an Secp256k1 EC private key. From here on out convert the private key to WIF then import it with ''bitcoinjs.ECPair.fromWIF(...)'' and let bitcoinjs create the address for that ECPair. This address is now what ''addr'' was before and the posting process can continue as it has before.
'''Post_time+post_uuidv4+Board_Owner_Address''' will supply additional entropy and guarantee, that the key will be unique for each post.
'''Auth_address''' is now treated as a persistent local secret. With it, it is possible to recover the address used to make the post and registered in the certificate(or re-register it, if it was deleted for performance reasons), not breaking editing and deleting posts ** not too much so anyways**.
That, of course means that adjustments to ''makePost(...)'', ''deletePost(...)'' and ''editPost(...)'' as well as ''checkContentJSON(...)'', ''checkCert(...)'' and ''createCert(...)'' would need to be made. Some important changes would be:
-The uuid for the post will be computed before the certificates and content.json files are checked(no big deal).
-The post time is no long the time of the post getting sent over the network, but the time the 'post' button is pressed(doesn't make much of a difference).
-The ''deletePost(...)'' and ''deletePost(...)'' functions must treat posts older then date_of_update differently since they still use the old scheme. An Idea would be to introduce a new anonWIF, have the CA name be millchanV2 **or something like that** and than treat the post differently depending on the CA name they are created with.
This method as the benefit of keeping the user-visible-behavior in tact(stuff like: Deleting the ''Auth_address'' will reset your anonymity(or rather identity)).
A new key for each post has, in general, the **small** added benefit of making anonymous posts more computationally expensive, which will help against spam attacks.

Thoughts on that?

>Such as?

For (probably) fast and easy solutions there would be resize-img([github](https://github.com/kevva/resize-img)) and jimp([github](https://github.com/oliver-moran/jimp), [npm](https://www.npmjs.com/package/jimp?activeTab=readme)). Not sure how easy you can import them, but if one of them works: Problem solved **at least for images**!
Alternatively something that would definitely work, is just writing the image en- and decoder yourself as well as an implementation for resizing them. In a way, that: `file -> img data -> byte array -> {resize} -> byte array -> new img data -> file`. This would be normally impossible, but we are in luck, since we have direct access to the filesystem, through the ZeroFrame api. There are some decoder libraries for this out there that you can use, for example [this](https://github.com/devongovett/png.js/blob/master/png.js) is one for png files, but finding them is tricky, so you probably need to write a lot of them from scratch... this is hard mode.

Yes, you could use [jsmpeg](https://github.com/phoboslab/jsmpeg)(more specifically just it's [decoder](https://github.com/phoboslab/jsmpeg/blob/master/src/mpeg1.js)) for mpeg, [mest](https://github.com/GlobalStudioES/mest-video-decoder)(more specifically it's x264 [decoder](https://github.com/GlobalStudioES/mest-video-decoder/tree/master/src/decoders/x264)) (also there is [Broadway.js](https://github.com/mbebenita/Broadway), which uses c, and parses it I'm uncertain how well this does work) for mp4 and for webm things get difficult any decoders that are currently out there(for javascript) seem to be stuck in various stages of testing/pre-alpha/alpha, I'd say the best bet here is [vp8-webm-javascript-decoder](https://github.com/dominikhlbg/vp8-webm-javascript-decoder) second best would be [jsvpx](https://github.com/jscodec/jsvpx).
>Doesn't the FileReader API return exactly that?

Basically what >>14a1b359-d385-4f35-891d-89bb40723979 said, but to elaborate:
>How safe is this?
Anonymity wise: It depends, zeronet is basically an huge BitTorrent network, only that you download and seed webpages instead of files. That means out of the box zeronet will communicate with peers of any zite(=website on zeronet) you visit and reveal your ip to them(other peers of that same zite). You can activate tor only mode to hide yourself from them, since you no longer share the zites with your ip, but rather through an automatically generated hidden service. Any communication is done through them, his makes you as basically as anonymous as you can be on tor.
In every other aspect you couldn't want more: Zites in general cannot be taken down/offline by any entity(even government sized actors, such as china for example) and do not cost a single penny to operate(=no flow of money involved).
The only way this place can die is if mcdev decides to (on purpose) break the source code of millchan and just leave, which he most likely wont do since /CP/ exists and he doesn't seem to mind it.
>Should I be using Tor?
Probably, can't hurt to do since we are handling cp here. If you're worried about speed choose an VPN. **At some point zeronet will get i2p support, which you could then use, as well**
>Is Zeronet safe on Windows?
Zeronet on windows comes bundled with tor, so if you use tor always mode, then yes. **Keep in mind however, that windows is able to access your machine at any time. Windows cannot be made fully secure. If you have the know-how and are able to, I'd strongly recommend you install any linux as your OS, it will increase your security by magnitudes.**

If that username was connected to your real identity, then that is **obviously** an issue. If it's not, you'll probably be fine. But that's most likely just my paranoia talking, since that would require an state sized actor to pull off, which is unlikely given the small size zeronet net is right now.

>>22d917c2-251b-4246-985b-78ba57d77427
>They have some rules about sites that require JavaScript or that require "unknown software" whatever that means.
Well, by the nature of zeronet all zites can be considered open source, since all zites are hosted everywhere, there can be no secret-sketchy-server-side-hidden code, that is possibly running an exploit. Even three letter exploits are more unlikely than on onionland, since there isn't someones home you could raid, to gain control over the server. Further more, since every peer that is in tor always mode is himself a hidden service, they would now need to deanonymize not just one, but hundreds of them to take this zite down. So wouldn't this be like heaven to TL2 guys? **I ask at no one in particular.**
>I wonder if someone is already working on a 0net client that doesn't rely on JavaScript.
Well you can use the `/raw/`-prefix before the zite address to get it without any js, but I'm not sure how easy it is to do stuff with that, since a lot of the zeronet api builds on js to be there.

posts.subject: Dumb ideas thread
posts.body:
Have you ever had an idea, but where then too lazy or just didn't have the time to make it reality?
Has this ever happened to you:
>Well this is an dumb idea, I just had and will forget in an hour, but I wonder what would happen, if someone would bother doing it?
Are you bored and want to kill some time being **somewhat** productive?

Than this is the thread for you! In this thread we post simple/dumb/interesting/cool ideas, in hope that someone at some later time is bored enough to give one of them a shot.

>>c046e1b9-1a9b-4193-882a-0fdc7a4076b8
Take normal 18+ legal porn images and use photoshop to replace the pussy in those images with cp cunny. Make a few of them and post these on the usual and mainstream outlets(4chan, 8chan, pornhub, facebook and so on).
'''Optional''': Let them spread for some months and then leak what those images where somewhere or tell them directly.
'''Level 2''': Automate the photoshop part and go onto mass production: Have an AI automatically detect the pussy and replace it with cunny. Kind of like that deepfake thing, a while back.

>>1c989ef0-557e-478f-a90c-c9c8fbf87f5c
>but it would still be possible to find a vulnerability which would allow them to inject code into a zite
However this depends on the zite owner to not have his zite susceptible to js injections, since the transmission of any code is protected by the same crypto(ec-dsa, if I'm not mistaken) as bitcoin, which is known to be secure. 
>getting access to the zite's private key or finding a vulnerability within ZeroNet
**Ignoring, that finding vulnerabilities in zeronet will be easier, because the project is pretty young**
These also apply to tor, if you have the private key of an hidden service, you can just pretend to be that hidden service, announce, that your IP changed and serve your malicious code on place of the original one.
> generated their own all.js from Millchan's source code
Even then, assuming you do this automatically, you'd need to trust, that wherever you get the code from is genuine, which is the same issue we had before. Maybe being shown a dif of the source code and then being asked whether or not to accept and use that update would be the best course of action until we get the ability to have /raw/, javascriptless zites.
>I reckon not much.
Yeah, I looked into it a bit and as things currently stand it is impossible to have any non-static content without js. This is due to the way the zeronet api is build, so until someone makes a api, that can be accessed with html forms, we have to wait.
>someone could write a "Millchan client" in like Python
This would solve some issues, however having to install a separate program will be an significant higher barrier of entry. This would also mean, that you'd need a program for each zite, which comes with an trust issue, since you are running these zites as full blown programs(or python scripts). But that is an scalability problem and not an issue, if you only make a program for millchan, so maybe this is a good idea.
>The forehead has the same length as her whole face.
You're right! This is what looked so off to me.

I still stand by what I said in my post.In my opinon using a local keymap would introduce some limitations, that my idea doesn't have. However, it also is complicated and relies on an constant post time**which helps with time manipulation in the json file, since the key, that signed that post is no longer the same** and an persistent local secret (auth address for millchan).
The implementation of using different private keys for each post didn't work, for some reason. If you have time, that you want to dedicate to this: [here](https://gitgud.io/mcdev/Millchan/tree/anon-posts)(Clearnet) is the link to the millchan repo. Maybe you can figure out why this doesn't work.

On a related note: nofish has recently implemented some kind of time consensus within the network**, I didn't have the time to really look into that, so take what I say here with a grain of salt**. I think it would be a good idea to use the network consensus time **if accessible** as post time, since that one can **supposedly** not be modified easily **at least not immediately on post time, someone could still manipulate the .json file manually. That one would only be preventable, if the post time of a post is signed by someone, that isn't the post author**.

That's fair. But I assure you that it's not and unlike on clearnet, I can actually prove that to you, since all zites on ZeroNet have to be open source. That's one of it's appealing properties in my opinion: There can not be any hidden server side code and there is no server that even could be v& and then controlled by some TLA. Everyone can see what the hub is doing. I made the hub in such a way, that it doesn't need any js (like most hubs), anyways.
Feel free to join it if you like.
>I'm afraid it might happen with other people as well due to the Pedo in the name.
Yeah, but I wanted it to be as obvious and transparent as possible for anyone. There were more people, then I thought, interested in joining the hub, once it grows a bit bigger, that (from what I could tell) weren't pedos.
>Did something happen
Nothing of importance, my hard drive broke and I lost my private key to that account. Do you have one, too?
>Nice. It sounds like something that could be pretty useful.
Yeah, let's see when I actually get to finish that.

>>17808da1-f5c5-4ee9-8352-4136d50e7854
>seems to me like saying JavaScript is de facto a safe language because it is executed in the client-side and therefore always readable by the users
Well, zites in general are safer that on clearnet. Even still, being required to enable js, to use dynamic zites is really insecure and something I hope will soon be, well, not required for zeronet.
>Perhaps a safer approach
Don't get me wrong, that '''is''' the safer approach. Don't forget: To trust is to wait until something betrays you.
Due to the way ZeroMe and hubs in general work, it is impossible for the hubs to be honeypots. Hubs act as storage zites, one could think of them as hard drives. No js from any hub(if a hub even has any js to offer) is ever executed, if you're using ZeroMe.
So in the case of js/html and browser level stuff, you're safe, sibyl and correlation attacks will still work nonetheless, but those work on basically anything right now, since they are really powerful attacks with very few assumptions.
But I guess this all requires somewhat deeper knowledge, on how things work, that not many people have, so there definitely is a point there.
Do you have a good idea on how I could better prove that it's safe/not a honeypot?
>**Yes.****We could talk there if you want.**
Sure, why not. You can add me, since my toxID is already public, you don't have to post yours. Unless you want to post it, in which case: Should we make a tox thread?

>All the "New users" in ZeroMe as people who posted in the Pedohub?
>Also, will everything will be empty for a new user until he/she starts following some random people?
No. Not directly anyways, the every account and it's content is stored on the hub the user registered his account to. (If you comment on a post from another hub, than your content is stored twice, once on the hub you're on and once on the hub of the user you commented under)
This means if you visit a hub all posts of all users on that hub become visible to you. To help to get new users started, there is something called the 'ZeroMe user registry' that keeps track of all users that have an id from zeroid or zeroverse, these are the users you see in the 'New users'-section on the right. This means you are able to see(some) user accounts without downloading the hub they are on. If you click on their profile it asks you to download the hub in order for you to view their posts. If you want to see as much posts as possible I suggest visiting all hubs listed [here](/1GLndW2MJn7japuF3X2tbfBqgPMR52zaLQ).

Do you think it would be beneficial for performance to have all clearnet posted by a single user (all posts from the clearnet board in one data.json and all images in one folder) or just to make new addresses for each post? I would think the first one would be best, because it will introduce less bloat, allows easy separation of clearnet posts and zeronet posts and the time taken to read through one really big data.json should be about the same as ready through many small ones.

>>0bb8f7cc-0ced-405e-acf2-f6201c9a0cdd

You can use [siteClone](1DocsYf2tZVVMEMJFHiDsppmFicZCWkVv1/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/#siteclone). Although the documentation says you need admin permission, if your zite doesn't have that permission, the user will just be prompted whether or not he wants to clone the zite.
You can look at the [gitcenter source code](/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/repo/file/?18r929Hq8hE5Pi9Zf7ovMQVyn3WcGfxMgu/main/dist/js/repo.js@master#L2074) as a reference.

>The hub owner has access to the hubs's private key.
>The means they can modify and sign the data.json file of any user.
>Unfortunately, as far as I know, currently there isn't a user-friendly way of modifying those files.
Why not use the `## Board Owner` interface non-merger millchan has right now?

On a related note: I just noticed, that [Blacklist] is gone on hub version
Will you reimplement this? Transparent moderation was one of millchans big strengths.
This could be done, by having making a `data/mods` dir and putting another content.json in there. Make it only signable by a `[BitcoinAddress]#owner/[UserName]` certificate signed by the private key of the hub. That certificate will be generated on hub generation. `data/mods/1SomeAddress/data.json` will then contain the all mod actions. 
This could also easily be adapted for a board volunteer system, where the BO makes an `[BitcoinAddress]#mod/[UserName]` certificate with the hub private key and then gives that to the new mod.

>Either way, I think a single user would be the better option.
Probably, I think a new user for each mirrored thread would be the best of both then.

EDIT:

<3

>>24ed5d36-d3f0-43ac-ac6a-55bb64af1f84
>Not sure if that's what you mean already.
No.
>You could just define a mods.json file 
>stored in the user's directory.
Not sure if you mean `users/mods.json` or `users/1ForEachAddress/mods.json`. In the first case a mod would be able to modify posts and actions of any other mod which would be an issue. The second case would do mostly the same as having a separate `users/[...]` and `mods/[...]` directory, only that having separate directories allows you to have separate `content.json`-files, that govern what mods and users** and Volunteers** could do. Having each user have the ability to have a mods.json file makes you depend on whether or not it is possible to cram all mod permissions together with the anon permissions together in one file.
It will also make it easier to allow mods to post as anons, as soon as [this](/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/repo/issues/view/?1P4w4Rvh4vS9r6G5xTiSh8qEW87EKZtnJB/8@1DfrA2M9Qra6stqT6tzwNMYNweswY54KAC) zeronet issue gets resolved.

**Also I think having mods in separate folders will make it easier to maintain and transparent who actually is and ever was a mod with just the zeronet-data folder, the data structure in general would be nicer (keep things that belong together in the same place)**

**I made a (more) specific plan on how moderation on millchan merger could work on [gitgud](https://gitgud.io/mcdev/Millchan/issues/14)(Clearnet). Opinions on that?**

>>68d3ecb9-f73b-42b4-90b7-c38fb259879c
Sorry, for the late reply, I totally missed new posts here, over all the other two letter cosplay**/camwhore(?)** board posts.
**Please accept this somewhat lewd loli as apology **
>I'm new here, what's the best places to hang out?
[ZeroMe](/1MeFqFfFFGQfa1J3gJyYYUvb5Lksczq7nH), [Millchan](/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA), [ZeroTalk](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT) and [ThunderWave](/1CWkZv7fQAKxTVjZVrLZ8VHcrN6YGGcdky) are currently the most active places in general.
For more on topic stuff **not necessarily CP** there is this place but also [>>>/CP/](/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/?:users/1PuqutSyC1dVVBzi7Ce8vAj1wmXrtguprN:CP:0), [>>>/LoSwim/](/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/?:users/1KWLNhX3kaALRaK7p6J1FgrWUWWfFxT6uD:LoSwim:0) and [>>>/younglove/](/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/?:users/1Sp6HCDXwnrRaRMRaaR8RuNXu2vqynJ6o:younglove:0), millchan engine [>>>/sweet/](/17gCoQDCAAoQkzKRiajFNUAhnVD2gSNmuC/?:1Sweetyby4djYXnkVZGzTzyZ5gCWQ7ooN:0) and [>>>/CP/](/17gCoQDCAAoQkzKRiajFNUAhnVD2gSNmuC/?:1CheeseGbTxP5Hij7EDjipWZ7UDJZTaPey:0) as well as the outdated millchan clones [PedoChan](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1P5AXm2CuAf2fx4FxD4iMu8sq8QB7fH8x2) and [ChildChan](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Jm7uc3bmqPEBm6xdNoF8xi3y2uBBCn6pJ).
>How do you best opsec here?
In my opinion:
-ZeroNet is essentially BitTorrent, so you connect directly to other peers... '''Run ZeroNet in tor-always-mode to remain anonymous!''' 
-Be aware, that since nothing here is central, everyone knows everything that can store/upload and see on any zite.
-Until [this](/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/repo/issues/view/?1P4w4Rvh4vS9r6G5xTiSh8qEW87EKZtnJB/8@1DfrA2M9Qra6stqT6tzwNMYNweswY54KAC) issue gets resolved: All zites can have one and only one user address at once under the hood. That means all posts you make anywhere are by design pseudonymous not anonymous and that includes millchan as well. Backup the privatekeys of zites that you own and **after that** regularly delete your users.json file to reset your ZeroNet identities.
>There should be a guide to help people like me out like on onion places.
I'm planning to do something like topic links once [this](/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/repo/issues/view/?1P4w4Rvh4vS9r6G5xTiSh8qEW87EKZtnJB/5@1DfrA2M9Qra6stqT6tzwNMYNweswY54KAC) gets implemented.

>>357dc971-68cc-4a47-bdbc-540d62dcc9c7
>22908 error tiny-secp256k1@1.1.1 install: `node-gyp rebuild`
>22908 error Exit status 1
>22909 error Failed at the tiny-secp256k1@1.1.1 install script.
>22909 error This is probably not a problem with npm. There is likely additional logging output above.
>22910 verbose exit [ 1, true ]

You problem seems to be missing compilation dependencies for the binary version of `secp256k1`. I take it you followed the instructions on GitCenter(outdated) and not Gitgud?

Anyways you need the gnu compiler collection for c++, which you can install by `sudo dnf install gcc-c++` for fedora or `sudo apt-get install g++` for debian(and ubuntu). Do that and try `npm install` again.

**Also: Do you want to make yourself an Millchan clone or an Millchan Engine clone? Because the code for Millchan Engine is only halfway through implementing advanced modding and does break some things.**

>>16413e00-f96c-4c5d-b5d5-bd8b68e95734
>I already had g++ installed
Are you sure? Maybe just run `sudo apt-get install g++` just to be sure.

What OS are you on? Compiled for me just fine on a clean Debian 9.

>>33495bad-1898-4aac-a3a1-3e99de6ed732
>Xenial Xerus.
How up to date are the repos kept? Maybe a dependency for `tiny-secp256k1` wasn't in g++ back then.
It definitely fails at `tiny-secp256k1` maybe try to only `npm install tiny-secp256k1` and see if that gives you more details.

>>3f3bd39a-eac3-4284-8acc-6fcc22a11fe5
Well I'm beat at this point.
Try doing what >>254af954-45a2-441a-9079-7b75dc232641 said and see if that gets you more info.
**Although its weird, that the tiny-secp256k1 issue just went away after you did the npm install alone.**

Which things, specifically?
There are known issues on older browsers(mainly stale or somewhat active FireFox forks that were forked before the quantum update), so that could be one reason, but only getting a ZeroID should not affect __any__ zites you aren't logged in(selected the ZeroID certificate) to. If it does, you should be worried.
>if we say something that goes against zeronet purpose, we gets shadowbanned.
You don't get shadowbanned, at least not globally. Generally, individual users can choose to mute you(just like they can choose to do here). If someone runs a public blocklist, they can choose to add you to it as well, that's about it. Specific zites can implement features that would allow the moderators of that zite to shadowban people, but neither ZeroTalk nor any of the zites I know of have done so.
>kxoid, does not work
kxoid requires you to install the `PeerMessage ` plugin, which allows zites to make p2p connections from your zeronet client to other  zeronet clients.

>>60030e2d-239a-417b-a7af-17dcbf0d19d6
It is possible to implement that, but no, currently not. The reason for that is that the millchan devs have absolutely no control over what the site does and how it's configured. '''Only''' the board owner can do that, but that can also mean that the owner of a hub can set the files on it to required which will download all of them to everyones computer automatically. In the case of, for example, child porn this is a big issue.

Hubs on their own aren't really anything special, they are just regular zites, with a marker that tells ZeroNet that it's data can be used by millchan.
There is a list of (to my knowledge) all millchan hubs that innocentchild maintains (or at least used to maintain, I'm not sure if innocentchild is still around):
